questions.explanation: Suggests aspiration or tube displacement into the lung.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a busy med-surg floor during morning shift, the nurse checks on Mr. Al-Rashid, multiple clients on a medical-surgical unit, who is receiving routine care activities. The RN is working with two UAPs and has six assigned clients.

Which task can the RN safely delegate to unlicensed assistive personnel?
options: Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
Document intake and output measurements
Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Obtain vital signs on a stable post-op client
questions.explanation: Requires nursing judgment and swallowing assessment; cannot be delegated.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 28-year-old at a prenatal visit appearing anxious and withdrawn (Ms. Kowalski) in an outpatient obstetric clinic. The client is prescribed routine prenatal care. The client minimizes injuries and partner controls all conversation.

Which interview technique is most appropriate?
options: Injuries in various stages of healing with inconsistent explanations
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
Provide information about domestic violence resources and safety planning
Document findings objectively using body maps and photographs with consent
Partner appears concerned and attentive
Client denies abuse when partner is present
questions.explanation: Pattern highly suspicious for repeated non-accidental trauma.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Carter, a 45-year-old with a hemorrhagic stroke in a neuro step-down unit, indicate active treatment with hyperosmolar therapy. The nurse performs hourly cranial nerve checks.

What finding indicates the client's ICP is worsening?
options: ICP waveform showing regular P1>P2 pattern
Urine output of 55 mL/hour
Temperature of 99.2 F (37.3 C)
A sudden decrease in level of consciousness
Decorticate posturing noted during stimulation
Client reports headache rated 4/10
questions.explanation: LOC decline is the earliest and most important sign of worsening ICP.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 25-year-old with family history of anesthesia complications (Ms. Wilson) in a surgical suite. The client is on emergency protocol activation. End-tidal CO2 is rapidly rising with muscle rigidity noted.

Which medication should the nurse prepare to administer?
options: Initiate active cooling measures
Discontinue all triggering agents and hyperventilate with 100% oxygen
Obtain arterial blood gas to assess metabolic acidosis
Prepare dantrolene sodium for immediate IV administration
Family history of unexplained perioperative death
Rapidly rising end-tidal CO2 with unexplained tachycardia and rigidity
questions.explanation: First priority is to stop causative agents and increase oxygen delivery.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 45-year-old recently divorced adult (Ms. Chen) in an outpatient crisis center regarding day-treatment program. Session notes mention escalating hopelessness.

What observation places the client at highest risk for self-harm?
options: Client refuses to contract for safety after disclosing a lethal plan
Client requests extra art supplies for distraction
Client journals feelings during group therapy
Client sleeps six hours overnight
Client attends all therapy groups and participates
Client states, 'I finally figured out how to make the pain stop tonight.'
questions.explanation: Refusal indicates the plan is active and requires continuous observation.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 4-year-old with asthma exacerbation (Ms. Gomez) in an emergency department. The client is receiving nebulized beta-agonists and steroids. The child has been receiving back-to-back treatments.

Which assessment requires immediate intervention?
options: Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Heart rate 160/min while crying
Altered mental status with lethargy
Pulse oximetry falling to 88% despite oxygen support
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
questions.explanation: Decreased responsiveness signals severe hypoxia and CO2 retention.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Mr. Lopez, a 22-year-old in the transition phase of labor in a labor room, who is currently on natural childbirth support. The client reports feeling the urge to push but is only 8 cm dilated.

What is the nurse's priority intervention based on the fetal monitor tracing?
options: Administer oxygen via nasal cannula at 2 L/min
Reposition the client to the left lateral or knee-chest position
Increase the IV fluid rate
Encourage the client to blow in short breaths and not push
Prepare for immediate cesarean section
Discontinue the oxytocin infusion immediately
questions.explanation: Variable decelerations indicate cord compression; position change often relieves pressure.

questions.text:
While assessing a 28-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor (Ms. Romero) in a labor and delivery suite, the nurse notes the client is receiving continuous external fetal monitoring. Contractions are occurring every 3 minutes lasting 60 seconds.

Which finding on the monitor strip indicates fetal compromise?
options: Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
questions.explanation: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes pain management and antibiotics for an 82-year-old post-op day 2 from hip replacement with sudden confusion (Dr. Bennett) in an orthopedic unit. Family reports the client was oriented and independent before surgery.

Which factor is most likely contributing to the acute confusion?
options: Client cannot recall short-term events
Investigate for underlying infection, hypoxia, or metabolic disturbance
Family requests pharmacologic sedation
Gradual cognitive decline over several years
Acute onset of confusion with fluctuating level of consciousness
Recent addition of multiple new medications including opioids and anticholinergics
questions.explanation: Delirium has reversible causes that must be identified and treated.

questions.text:
While assessing a 25-year-old trauma patient with rib fractures (Mr. Yang) in a trauma bay, the nurse notes the client is receiving mechanical ventilation. The client's oxygen saturation is declining rapidly despite ventilator adjustments.

What intervention must the nurse anticipate immediately?
options: Tracheal deviation away from the affected side with severe dyspnea
Hypotension, distended neck veins, and rapid deterioration
Chest X-ray confirmation before treatment
Unilateral chest pain worsening with deep breathing
Prepare for immediate needle thoracostomy followed by chest tube insertion
Subcutaneous emphysema palpable at the insertion site
questions.explanation: Tracheal shift indicates mediastinal displacement from tension pneumothorax.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 4-year-old toddler (Ms. Okafor) in a pediatric ward. The client is on hospitalization for pneumonia. The child is bored and the parents ask for activity recommendations.

Which statement by the parent indicates a need for further teaching?
options: Give the child a 50-piece jigsaw puzzle
Not pulling up to a standing position
Speaking 3-5 words
My baby sits without support
Provide a medical kit or puppets for dramatic play
I can leave the baby in the bathtub for a minute to get a towel
questions.explanation: By 15 months, a child should be walking or at least cruising/standing. Not pulling up is a delay.

questions.text:
While assessing a 70-year-old with ischemic cardiomyopathy and frequent PVCs (Mr. Alvarez) in a medical ICU, the nurse notes the client is receiving lidocaine at 1.5 mg/min. The client reports new light-headedness after an hour of therapy.

Which finding signals that the lidocaine at 1.5 mg/min should be paused?
options: Telemetry tracing that now shows a broadening QRS duration
Sudden confusion and tremors noted during neurologic checks
Complaint of mild metallic taste
Occasional premature ventricular contractions that match baseline frequency
Oxygen saturation trending 96% on 2 L/min nasal cannula
Client reporting localized IV site warmth
questions.explanation: A widening QRS indicates progression toward heart block from lidocaine toxicity.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mx. Santos, a 72-year-old with home oxygen presenting with worsening cough in an emergency department who is receiving antibiotics for suspected bacterial superinfection. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air.

What assessment finding indicates the client's status is worsening?
options: Maintain oxygen saturation between 88-92% using low-flow oxygen
Decreasing level of consciousness with CO2 retention
Administer methylprednisolone to reduce airway inflammation
Bilateral expiratory wheezes throughout lung fields
Increase oxygen to maintain saturation above 95%
Respiratory rate of 24/min with prolonged expiration
questions.explanation: COPD patients rely on hypoxic drive; excessive oxygen can suppress respirations.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 70-year-old with heart failure (Ms. Chen) in a telemetry unit. Current therapy includes digoxin and furosemide therapy. The client reports seeing yellow halos around lights.

What is the priority assessment before administering this medication?
options: Decrease the heparin rate by 2 units/kg/hr
Stop the heparin infusion and notify the provider
Obtain a serum digoxin level and potassium level
Administer the insulin via gravity drip
Verify the insulin dose and rate with a second registered nurse
Administer the next dose of digoxin
questions.explanation: A PTT of 98 is >3x control, indicating high bleeding risk. The infusion should be held.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a regional burn center, the nurse checks on Mr. Kaur, a 28-year-old on hour 16 of burn resuscitation, who is receiving lactated Ringer's infusion. Urine output has been trending 25 mL/hour for the past 3 hours.

Which formula guides initial fluid replacement?
options: Administer half of calculated 24-hour fluid volume in the first 8 hours
Hematocrit elevation to 52%
Blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg
Urine output maintained at 30-50 mL/hour or 0.5 mL/kg/hour
Urine output consistently below 30 mL/hour despite aggressive fluids
Client reports severe pain at burn sites
questions.explanation: Parkland formula requires frontloading fluids in the first 8 hours post-burn.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Mr. Haddad, a 62-year-old after knee arthroplasty in an orthopedic unit, who is currently on a negative pressure dressing. Family members are assisting with repositioning.

Which action should the nurse take first to reduce infection risk?
options: Perform hand hygiene and don clean gloves before touching the incision
Keep the incision covered when around pets or crowded areas
Change the dressing only if it becomes fully saturated
Massage around the incision to promote circulation
Pack the incision with cotton balls soaked in peroxide
Teach the client to report increasing drainage volume or odor
questions.explanation: Hand hygiene remains the highest-leverage intervention to prevent infection.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 45-year-old on day 2 of chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma (Ms. Silva) in a cancer center. The client is prescribed rasburicase administration. Urine output has been adequate at 150 mL/hour.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Potassium 6.8 mEq/L, phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL, calcium 6.9 mg/dL
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
Cardiac monitor showing peaked T waves and widened QRS
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
Urine pH of 6.5
questions.explanation: The classic TLS triad: hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in an oncology clinic, the nurse checks on Mr. Okoye, a 70-year-old opioid-naive patient starting oral oxycodone, who is receiving immediate-release opioids for cancer pain. The client has renal insufficiency with a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL.

Which assessment finding requires withholding the opioid dose?
options: Client sleeping but easily arousable with normal respirations
Blood pressure slightly decreased from baseline
Keep naloxone readily available at the bedside
Respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute with sedation score of 3
Pinpoint pupils with decreased level of consciousness
Client reports pain level of 6/10
questions.explanation: Opioid antagonist must be immediately accessible to reverse respiratory depression.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Ms. Chenoweth, a 45-year-old requiring urinary catheterization in a medical-surgical unit, indicate active treatment with insertion of an indwelling Foley catheter. The nurse is setting up the sterile tray on the bedside table.

How should the nurse proceed to maintain the sterile field?
options: Pour the saline solution without splashing onto the sterile field
Reach over the sterile field to grab a supply
Keep the sterile field in direct line of sight at all times
Place the sterile field 1 inch from the edge of the table
Use a sterile gloved hand to adjust the face mask
Discard the entire sterile field and start over with a new kit
questions.explanation: Moisture allows bacteria to travel through the sterile drape (wicking), contaminating the field.

questions.text:
A nurse in an emergency department is managing the care of Ms. Nguyen, a 24-year-old with major depressive disorder, who is undergoing psychiatric evaluation. The client admits to having a plan to overdose on medication.

Which statement by the client requires immediate follow-up?
options: I have given away my prized guitar collection
Assign a staff member to stay with the client at all times (1:1 observation)
Walk with the client to a quiet area and speak in a calm, low voice
Ask the client why they feel this way
Administer a sedative immediately
Contract for safety
questions.explanation: Giving away possessions is a classic warning sign of impending suicide attempt.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 72-year-old with atrial fibrillation and a healed peptic ulcer (Mr. Carter) in an outpatient anticoagulation clinic regarding warfarin 5 mg daily. The INR today is 2.4 and the client is eager to resume normal activities.

Which instruction must the nurse emphasize before discharge?
options: Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
Inform every healthcare provider and dentist about warfarin therapy
Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Report any bruising, nosebleeds, or black stools to the provider immediately
Keep a blood pressure log every morning
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
questions.explanation: All clinicians must know about anticoagulation before procedures or prescriptions.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a transitional care clinic is discussing the care plan for Mr. Alvarez, a 76-year-old with newly prescribed medications after hospitalization, who is receiving medication reconciliation. Home medications include anticoagulants, NSAIDs, and antiplatelets.

Which medication should the nurse question for this elderly client?
options: Client sees multiple specialists
Diphenhydramine prescribed for sleep in an 82-year-old
Family helps manage medication administration
Concurrent use of warfarin, aspirin, and ibuprofen
Client uses a weekly pill organizer
New cognitive impairment with urinary retention and dry mouth
questions.explanation: Beers Criteria identifies antihistamines as potentially inappropriate for elderly due to anticholinergic effects.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in an emergency department is discussing the care plan for Mr. Rossi, a 72-year-old with a history of aortic aneurysm, who is receiving blood pressure management. The client reports a tearing sensation in the chest radiating to the back.

Which physiological mechanism explains the client's current symptoms?
options: Right ventricular failure causing systemic congestion
Auscultate the second intercostal space right sternal border
Pulmonary venous congestion due to backward failure of the left ventricle
Auscultate the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line
Palpate the carotid arteries simultaneously
Assess blood pressure in both arms to check for discrepancy
questions.explanation: Left ventricular failure causes blood to back up into the pulmonary veins, leading to dyspnea.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a community health telehealth follow-up is discussing the care plan for Mr. Rossi, a 29-year-old with type 1 diabetes experiencing viral gastroenteritis, who is receiving basal-bolus insulin. The client has been vomiting but can sip clear liquids.

Which statement shows correct understanding of sick-day insulin management?
options: Take double the usual correction bolus at bedtime
Continue basal insulin even if intake is limited
Skip ketone testing if glucose stays under 180 mg/dL
Avoid electrolyte drinks because they contain sodium
Check blood glucose and ketones every 3 to 4 hours
Hold all insulin doses until solid food resumes
questions.explanation: Basal insulin prevents ketosis and must continue during illness.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 36-week gestation infant, appropriate for gestational age (Mr. Alvarez) in a level II NICU. The client is receiving IV glucose supplementation. The infant has been jittery with a high-pitched cry.

What intervention should the nurse implement first for this at-risk infant?
options: Pink, active infant with strong cry
Jitteriness, lethargy, and poor feeding within the first hours of life
Initiate early and frequent breastfeeding every 2-3 hours
Blood glucose level of 35 mg/dL at 1 hour of age
Term infant born via scheduled cesarean section
Glucose level of 55 mg/dL at 4 hours of life
questions.explanation: These are classic signs of neonatal hypoglycemia requiring immediate glucose check.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 28-year-old with sickle cell disease reporting severe chest and back pain (Mr. Okoye) in an emergency department. Current therapy includes IV opioid analgesia and hydration. Pain started 6 hours ago and rates it 9/10.

What assessment finding indicates the crisis is worsening?
options: Client requests heating pad for painful joints
Initiate aggressive pain management with opioids around-the-clock
Administer IV fluids at 1.5 times maintenance to promote hemodilution
Hemoglobin of 8 g/dL
Encourage bed rest to conserve energy
New onset fever, chest pain, and decreased oxygen saturation
questions.explanation: Adequate analgesia is essential; use scheduled dosing rather than PRN only.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of inhalational anesthetic agents for a 32-year-old undergoing general anesthesia for orthopedic surgery (Ms. Mbatha) in an operating room, the nurse performs an assessment. The client suddenly develops tachycardia and rigidity during the procedure.

Which assessment finding during surgery suggests malignant hyperthermia?
options: Temperature spiking to 105°F (40.6°C) or higher
Obtain arterial blood gas to assess metabolic acidosis
Initiate active cooling measures
Family history of unexplained perioperative death
Prepare dantrolene sodium for immediate IV administration
Rapidly rising end-tidal CO2 with unexplained tachycardia and rigidity
questions.explanation: Extreme hyperthermia is a late but characteristic sign of MH.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in an inpatient behavioral health unit, the nurse checks on Mr. Brown, a 17-year-old admitted for major depressive disorder, who is receiving SSRIs and cognitive behavioral therapy. The client is on 15-minute checks.

Which statement requires the fastest action?
options: Client sleeps six hours overnight
Client journals feelings during group therapy
Client states, 'I finally figured out how to make the pain stop tonight.'
Client attends all therapy groups and participates
Client requests extra art supplies for distraction
Client refuses to contract for safety after disclosing a lethal plan
questions.explanation: A specific statement about ending life tonight indicates imminent risk.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 41-year-old trauma patient (Ms. Silva) in an emergency department bay. Current therapy includes large-bore IV for potential transfusion. Hair covers the antecubital region and needs quick management.

What is the safest way to manage excess hair before starting the IV?
options: Use a sterile scalpel to remove hair close to the skin
Shave the area with a razor just before insertion
Leave the hair intact to avoid upsetting the client
Smooth the hair with a water-based lubricant before taping
Apply depilatory cream and wipe it off after three minutes
Use a single-patient clipper to trim hair down to stubble
questions.explanation: Clipping removes hair without causing micro-abrasions that raise infection risk.

questions.text:
In a surgical holding area, the nurse is evaluating a 45-year-old with limited English proficiency signing surgical consent (Ms. Romero) who is receiving interpreter services. The consent form is in English and no interpreter was present.

Which situation requires the nurse to intervene before the procedure?
options: Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Family members are present and supportive
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Client appears nervous about the procedure
questions.explanation: Indicates lack of understanding; consent may not be truly informed.

questions.text:
In an ICU, the nurse is evaluating a 55-year-old with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) (Ms. Chenoweth) who is receiving continuous IV insulin infusion. The nurse is preparing to adjust the infusion rate based on blood glucose levels.

What is the priority assessment before administering this medication?
options: Verify the insulin dose and rate with a second registered nurse
Administer the insulin via gravity drip
Administer the next dose of digoxin
Stop the heparin infusion and notify the provider
Decrease the heparin rate by 2 units/kg/hr
Obtain a serum digoxin level and potassium level
questions.explanation: Independent double-checks are standard of care for high-alert medications like IV insulin.

questions.text:
While assessing a 62-year-old presenting with left-sided weakness and slurred speech (Mr. Kaur) in an emergency department, the nurse notes the client is receiving alteplase infusion. Symptom onset was 90 minutes ago and CT shows no hemorrhage.

Which assessment finding is an absolute contraindication to tPA?
options: Client had major surgery 10 days ago
Blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL
Platelet count of 88,000/mm³
NIH Stroke Scale score of 8
Onset time documented at 4.5 hours ago
Client takes daily aspirin 81 mg
questions.explanation: Recent major surgery within 14 days increases hemorrhage risk.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in an emergency department is discussing the care plan for Mr. Park, a 24-year-old with major depressive disorder, who is receiving psychiatric evaluation. The client admits to having a plan to overdose on medication.

Which statement by the client requires immediate follow-up?
options: Contract for safety
Walk with the client to a quiet area and speak in a calm, low voice
Assign a staff member to stay with the client at all times (1:1 observation)
Ask the client why they feel this way
I have given away my prized guitar collection
Administer a sedative immediately
questions.explanation: Reducing stimulation and using a calm approach helps de-escalate manic behavior.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a high-risk obstetric unit, the nurse checks on Ms. Gomez, a 26-year-old with postpartum hypertension, who is receiving magnesium sulfate infusion. Deep tendon reflexes and respiratory status are trending every 30 minutes.

Which assessment should prompt the nurse to stop the infusion and follow the emergency protocol?
options: Blood pressure decreases from 158/102 to 146/94
Serum magnesium level of 9.0 mg/dL
Client describes mild nausea
Respiratory rate that falls to 10 breaths per minute
Magnesium level reported at 5.5 mg/dL
Client reports feeling warm and flushed
questions.explanation: Levels above the therapeutic range of 4-7 mg/dL indicate toxicity.

questions.text:
While assessing a 28-year-old 30 minutes post-vaginal delivery (Ms. Patel) in a labor and delivery unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving fundal massage and oxytocin infusion. The client delivered a 9-pound infant after prolonged labor.

Which assessment finding indicates postpartum hemorrhage?
options: Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
Fundus firm at umbilicus level
Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
Fundus boggy and displaced to the right above the umbilicus
Lochia rubra with small clots
Blood loss exceeding 500 mL vaginal or 1000 mL cesarean
questions.explanation: Signs of hypovolemic shock requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 30-year-old with a large abdominal wound (Ms. Osei) in a wound care clinic to administer sterile wound irrigation and packing. The nurse opens a bottle of sterile saline solution.

Which observation indicates the sterile field has been contaminated?
options: Use a sterile gloved hand to adjust the face mask
Place the sterile field 1 inch from the edge of the table
Keep the sterile field in direct line of sight at all times
Discard the entire sterile field and start over with a new kit
Pour the saline solution without splashing onto the sterile field
Reach over the sterile field to grab a supply
questions.explanation: Turning the back to a sterile field renders it unmonitored and potentially contaminated.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 68-year-old with COPD admitted for increased dyspnea and purulent sputum (Ms. Gomez) in a medical unit. The client is prescribed nebulized bronchodilators and systemic corticosteroids. The client is tripod positioning and using pursed-lip breathing.

Which intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Bilateral expiratory wheezes throughout lung fields
Increase oxygen to maintain saturation above 95%
Administer methylprednisolone to reduce airway inflammation
Respiratory rate of 24/min with prolonged expiration
Decreasing level of consciousness with CO2 retention
Maintain oxygen saturation between 88-92% using low-flow oxygen
questions.explanation: Corticosteroids shorten exacerbation duration and are first-line therapy.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Harper (a 32-year-old post-central line insertion with sudden dyspnea), asks the nurse in a medical ICU about their supplemental oxygen. The client received a subclavian line 30 minutes ago.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Chest X-ray confirmation before treatment
Absent breath sounds with hyperresonance to percussion on one side
Prepare for immediate needle thoracostomy followed by chest tube insertion
Subcutaneous emphysema palpable at the insertion site
Unilateral chest pain worsening with deep breathing
Tracheal deviation away from the affected side with severe dyspnea
questions.explanation: Classic findings of pneumothorax; hyperresonance indicates air-filled space.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Rodriguez, post-operative clients requiring various interventions in a surgical recovery unit, who is currently on post-op care protocols. Staffing is adequate with a mix of RNs, LPNs, and UAPs.

Which task can the RN safely delegate to unlicensed assistive personnel?
options: Document intake and output measurements
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
Assist a client with ambulation using a gait belt
Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
questions.explanation: Initial assessments require RN clinical judgment and cannot be delegated.

questions.text:
A nurse in a surgical unit is managing the care of Ms. Yamamoto, a 54-year-old two days after colorectal surgery, who is undergoing a closed suction drain. The client is learning to care for the incision at home.

What instruction best protects the client from a postoperative wound infection?
options: Pack the incision with cotton balls soaked in peroxide
Massage around the incision to promote circulation
Perform hand hygiene and don clean gloves before touching the incision
Change the dressing only if it becomes fully saturated
Teach the client to report increasing drainage volume or odor
Keep the incision covered when around pets or crowded areas
questions.explanation: Hand hygiene remains the highest-leverage intervention to prevent infection.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 68-year-old receiving continuous tube feeding via NG tube (Ms. Mbatha) in a long-term acute care facility to administer high-protein enteral formula at 60 mL/hour. The client has been NPO for 5 days following stroke.

Which complication is the client experiencing?
options: Client reports feeling bloated
Sudden respiratory distress with diminished breath sounds
Gastric residual of 75 mL
Flush the tube with 30 mL water before and after feeding
Verify tube placement by checking pH of aspirate and comparing to X-ray
Maintain head of bed elevation at least 30-45 degrees during and after feeding
questions.explanation: Suggests aspiration or tube displacement into the lung.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of nebulized beta-agonists and steroids for a 4-year-old with asthma exacerbation (Ms. Wilson) in an emergency department, the nurse performs an assessment. The child has been receiving back-to-back treatments.

Which cue suggests impending respiratory failure?
options: Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
Altered mental status with lethargy
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
Heart rate 160/min while crying
Suprasternal and intercostal retractions that suddenly diminish
questions.explanation: Decreased responsiveness signals severe hypoxia and CO2 retention.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 68-year-old post-op day 3 from bowel resection (Ms. Yamamoto) in a surgical ICU. The client is prescribed vasopressor support. Blood cultures are pending and lactate is 4.2 mmol/L.

Which assessment finding is the earliest indicator of septic shock?
options: Lactate level trending down from 4.2 to 2.1 mmol/L
Temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C)
Urine output of 35 mL/hour after fluid bolus
Obtain blood cultures before initiating antibiotics
White blood cell count of 18,000/mm³
Mean arterial pressure drops below 65 mm Hg despite fluids
questions.explanation: Clearing lactate indicates improved tissue perfusion.

questions.text:
A nurse in an emergency department is managing the care of Mr. Al-Rashid, a 28-year-old with sickle cell disease reporting severe chest and back pain, who is undergoing IV opioid analgesia and hydration. Pain started 6 hours ago and rates it 9/10.

What assessment finding indicates the crisis is worsening?
options: Encourage bed rest to conserve energy
New onset fever, chest pain, and decreased oxygen saturation
Client requests heating pad for painful joints
Hemoglobin of 8 g/dL
Initiate aggressive pain management with opioids around-the-clock
Administer IV fluids at 1.5 times maintenance to promote hemodilution
questions.explanation: Triad of acute chest syndrome, a life-threatening complication.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 28-year-old recently started on clozapine (Mx. Santos) in a mental health treatment facility. The client is receiving atypical antipsychotic with weekly monitoring. The client develops fever, confusion, and muscle rigidity.

What assessment finding indicates a serious medication reaction?
options: Client reports feeling drowsy in the afternoon
Weight gain of 5 pounds over 2 months
Teach client to report fever, sore throat, or flu-like symptoms immediately
Mild hand tremor noted during medication administration
Temperature 104°F (40°C) with severe muscle rigidity and altered mental status
White blood cell count of 2,000/mm³ with neutropenia
questions.explanation: Early signs of agranulocytosis require urgent medical evaluation.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Mbatha, a 22-year-old with a traumatic brain injury in a neuro ICU, who is currently on ventricular drain with ICP monitoring. Sedation has been lightened for a neuro exam.

Which cue should prompt the nurse to prepare for rapid intervention?
options: ICP waveform showing regular P1>P2 pattern
Urine output of 55 mL/hour
Widening pulse pressure with bradycardia
Temperature of 99.2 F (37.3 C)
A sudden decrease in level of consciousness
Client reports headache rated 4/10
questions.explanation: Cushing response indicates rising ICP and brainstem compression.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in an orthopedic unit is discussing the care plan for Ms. Yamamoto, a 23-year-old with a tibial fracture and new cast applied 4 hours ago, who is receiving elevation and ice application. The client reports increasing pain despite opioid administration.

Which assessment finding is the earliest sign of compartment syndrome?
options: Paresthesia and decreased sensation in the affected extremity
Client reports the cast feels tight
Bivalve the cast immediately and remove all constrictive dressings
Pain with passive stretching of muscles in the affected compartment
Affected limb is cool to touch
Absence of pulses in the affected extremity
questions.explanation: Nerve ischemia indicates advanced compartment syndrome.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 52-year-old beginning chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ms. Rodriguez) in an oncology unit regarding aggressive IV hydration and allopurinol. Pre-treatment labs show high white blood cell count with large tumor burden.

What intervention should the nurse prioritize?
options: Maintain urine output of at least 2-3 L/day with IV hydration
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
Potassium 6.8 mEq/L, phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL, calcium 6.9 mg/dL
Urine pH of 6.5
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
questions.explanation: High urine flow prevents crystal formation and flushes metabolites.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 58-year-old with septic shock on vasopressor support (Mr. Wallace) in a medical ICU to administer norepinephrine infusion. Creatinine rose from 1.1 to 2.4 mg/dL in 24 hours.

Which laboratory finding is the earliest indicator of acute kidney injury?
options: Urine output less than 0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 consecutive hours
Serum creatinine increase of 0.3 mg/dL or more within 48 hours
Urine specific gravity of 1.010
Potassium level of 6.2 mEq/L with peaked T waves on ECG
BUN/creatinine ratio of 15:1
Client reports nausea and fatigue
questions.explanation: Oliguria is a defining characteristic of AKI.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Mbatha (a 58-year-old receiving IV morphine for post-operative pain), is admitted to a surgical recovery unit for PCA morphine with basal rate. The client has obstructive sleep apnea and received a bolus dose 30 minutes ago.

Which vital sign is most important to monitor?
options: Client sleeping but easily arousable with normal respirations
Blood pressure slightly decreased from baseline
Inability to arouse the client with verbal or tactile stimulation
Pinpoint pupils with decreased level of consciousness
Keep naloxone readily available at the bedside
Client reports pain level of 6/10
questions.explanation: Profound sedation precedes apnea and requires immediate intervention.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 52-year-old admitted with active pulmonary tuberculosis (Ms. Harper) in a medical unit regarding multi-drug anti-tubercular regimen. Sputum cultures are positive for acid-fast bacilli.

Which type of isolation precaution is required for this client?
options: Place the client in a negative pressure isolation room
Keep the door closed at all times
Wear an N95 respirator before entering the room
Cohort the client with another TB patient
Standard precautions alone are adequate
Wear a surgical mask, which is sufficient for TB
questions.explanation: Airborne precautions require negative pressure to prevent organism spread.

questions.text:
In a regional burn center, the nurse is evaluating a 28-year-old on hour 16 of burn resuscitation (Mr. Okoye) who is receiving lactated Ringer's infusion. Urine output has been trending 25 mL/hour for the past 3 hours.

Which formula guides initial fluid replacement?
options: Administer half of calculated 24-hour fluid volume in the first 8 hours
Urine output consistently below 30 mL/hour despite aggressive fluids
Urine output maintained at 30-50 mL/hour or 0.5 mL/kg/hour
Client reports severe pain at burn sites
Hematocrit elevation to 52%
Blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg
questions.explanation: Parkland formula requires frontloading fluids in the first 8 hours post-burn.

questions.text:
A nurse in a medical ICU is managing the care of Mr. Kaur, a 24-year-old admitted for DKA now on hour 8 of treatment, who is undergoing IV regular insulin and potassium replacement. Glucose has dropped to 180 mg/dL but pH remains 7.28.

Which complication requires immediate recognition during treatment?
options: Client reports extreme thirst
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Add potassium to IV fluids once level drops below 5.3 mEq/L
Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
New onset headache, bradycardia, and altered mental status
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
questions.explanation: Insulin drives potassium intracellularly; replacement prevents cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 9-month-old infant (Mr. Haddad) in a pediatric clinic. The client's current regimen includes well-child checkup. The nurse is discussing home safety and developmental milestones with the parents.

Which finding should the nurse recognize as a developmental delay?
options: Give the child a 50-piece jigsaw puzzle
Speaking 3-5 words
Provide a medical kit or puppets for dramatic play
I can leave the baby in the bathtub for a minute to get a towel
Not pulling up to a standing position
My baby sits without support
questions.explanation: Preschoolers use magical thinking and play to cope with hospitalization fears.

questions.text:
While assessing a 70-year-old taking NSAIDs for arthritis with sudden weakness (Ms. Kowalski) in a medical unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving IV proton pump inhibitor infusion. Hemoglobin dropped from 12 to 8 g/dL overnight.

Which assessment finding indicates hypovolemic shock?
options: Heart rate 120/min with blood pressure 88/54 mm Hg
Establish large-bore IV access and initiate rapid fluid replacement
Type and crossmatch for packed red blood cells
Bowel sounds present in all four quadrants
Client reports epigastric pain
Nasogastric tube insertion to assess gastric contents
questions.explanation: Tachycardia with hypotension indicates significant volume loss.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in an urgent care clinic, the nurse checks on Ms. Wilson, a 6-month-old infant with decreased feeding and lethargy, who is receiving fluid replacement consideration. Anterior fontanel appears sunken and mucous membranes are dry.

What is the priority intervention for this child?
options: Urine specific gravity of 1.025
Capillary refill time greater than 3 seconds with cool extremities
Weight loss of 12% from pre-illness weight
Slightly decreased skin turgor on the abdomen
Sunken fontanel, absent tears, and dry mucous membranes
Child is fussy and irritable
questions.explanation: Indicates poor perfusion and potential hypovolemic shock.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a cardiac step-down unit, the nurse checks on Ms. Wilson, a 68-year-old recovering from a mechanical mitral valve replacement, who is receiving warfarin with bridge therapy. The client takes herbal supplements at home and prepares leafy greens daily.

What teaching point has the highest priority while reinforcing home safety on anticoagulants?
options: Report any bruising, nosebleeds, or black stools to the provider immediately
Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Keep vitamin K intake consistent rather than eliminating leafy vegetables
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
Keep a blood pressure log every morning
questions.explanation: Unusual bleeding can signal excessive anticoagulation and must be reported.

questions.text:
In a geriatric clinic, the nurse is evaluating an 80-year-old taking 12 daily medications including anticholinergics (Mr. Haddad) who is receiving comprehensive medication review. The client reports new-onset confusion and recent falls.

What adverse effect is most concerning with this medication combination?
options: Client sees multiple specialists
Diphenhydramine prescribed for sleep in an 82-year-old
Concurrent use of warfarin, aspirin, and ibuprofen
Client uses a weekly pill organizer
Family helps manage medication administration
New cognitive impairment with urinary retention and dry mouth
questions.explanation: Beers Criteria identifies antihistamines as potentially inappropriate for elderly due to anticholinergic effects.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 32-year-old primigravida with epidural analgesia (Mr. Brown) in a birthing center. The client is receiving internal fetal scalp electrode monitoring. The client is fully dilated and beginning to push.

Which finding on the monitor strip indicates fetal compromise?
options: Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
questions.explanation: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a medical ICU is discussing the care plan for Mr. Ibrahim, a 38-year-old with MG admitted for pneumonia, who is receiving plasma exchange. Bulbar symptoms are worsening with dysphagia and weak cough.

What intervention should the nurse anticipate first?
options: Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
Prepare for intubation with declining respiratory effort
Fasciculations, increased salivation, and miosis with bradycardia
Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Recent antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolone
questions.explanation: Both crisis types can cause respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a cardiac catheterization lab is discussing the care plan for Mx. Jordan, a 66-year-old with acute MI presenting with hypotension and pulmonary edema, who is receiving inotropic support and mechanical circulatory support consideration. The client has cold, clammy skin with decreased urine output.

Which medication is contraindicated in this situation?
options: Prepare for intra-aortic balloon pump or mechanical circulatory support
Cardiac index below 2.2 L/min/m² with elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
Blood pressure 88/60 mm Hg
Administer morphine for chest pain and anxiety
Initiate dobutamine to improve contractility and cardiac output
Lactate level elevated at 3.2 mmol/L
questions.explanation: Refractory cardiogenic shock may require mechanical assistance.

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old term infant born to a mother with gestational diabetes (Ms. Gomez) is being treated in a newborn nursery with early breastfeeding attempts. The infant weighed 4200 grams at birth.

Which newborn is at highest risk for hypoglycemia?
options: Pink, active infant with strong cry
Glucose level of 55 mg/dL at 4 hours of life
Jitteriness, lethargy, and poor feeding within the first hours of life
Initiate early and frequent breastfeeding every 2-3 hours
Term infant born via scheduled cesarean section
Blood glucose level of 35 mg/dL at 1 hour of age
questions.explanation: These are classic signs of neonatal hypoglycemia requiring immediate glucose check.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 66-year-old male two hours post anterior myocardial infarction (Mr. Singh) in a cardiac ICU. The client is prescribed lidocaine loading dose followed by 2 mg/min maintenance. Ventricular ectopy has persisted despite electrolyte correction.

Which finding signals that the lidocaine loading dose followed by 2 mg/min maintenance should be paused?
options: Oxygen saturation trending 96% on 2 L/min nasal cannula
Complaint of mild metallic taste
Telemetry tracing that now shows a broadening QRS duration
Serum potassium that dropped from 4.2 to 3.1 mEq/L
Occasional premature ventricular contractions that match baseline frequency
Client reporting localized IV site warmth
questions.explanation: A widening QRS indicates progression toward heart block from lidocaine toxicity.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 75-year-old with known Alzheimer's disease now more confused (Ms. Harper) in a skilled nursing facility. The client's current regimen includes urinary catheter for retention. Staff notes worsening agitation over the past 24 hours.

Which factor is most likely contributing to the acute confusion?
options: Investigate for underlying infection, hypoxia, or metabolic disturbance
Client cannot recall short-term events
Family requests pharmacologic sedation
Recent addition of multiple new medications including opioids and anticholinergics
Gradual cognitive decline over several years
Acute onset of confusion with fluctuating level of consciousness
questions.explanation: Delirium has reversible causes that must be identified and treated.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 35-year-old receiving IV antibiotics who suddenly develops hives and throat tightness (Mr. Okoye) in a medical unit. The client is prescribed epinephrine administration. The infusion was started 10 minutes ago.

What assessment finding confirms anaphylaxis?
options: Client reports feeling anxious and dizzy
Blood pressure 82/50 mm Hg with rapid, weak pulse
Stop the infusion and maintain IV access with normal saline
Administer diphenhydramine 50 mg IV after epinephrine
Administer epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg IM into the lateral thigh immediately
Urticaria spreading across the chest and arms
questions.explanation: Distributive shock from massive vasodilation requires immediate treatment.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in an outpatient cardiology clinic is discussing the care plan for Mx. Jordan, a 55-year-old with mitral valve stenosis, who is receiving monitoring for valve replacement. The nurse is performing a focused cardiac assessment.

Where should the nurse place the stethoscope to best assess this finding?
options: Right ventricular failure causing systemic congestion
Auscultate the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line
Pulmonary venous congestion due to backward failure of the left ventricle
Palpate the carotid arteries simultaneously
Assess blood pressure in both arms to check for discrepancy
Auscultate the second intercostal space right sternal border
questions.explanation: This is the mitral area (apex), best for hearing mitral valve sounds and S3/S4.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a medical ICU is discussing the care plan for Ms. Chen, a 58-year-old on mechanical ventilation for 5 days post-ARDS, who is receiving pressure support ventilation. Sedation has been lightened and the client follows commands.

Which assessment supports successful extubation?
options: Strong cough with copious secretions managed independently
Respiratory rate climbing from 18 to 35/min with accessory muscle use
Rapid shallow breathing index below 105 with PEEP of 5 cm H2O
Client reports feeling anxious during the trial
Heart rate increase from 78 to 88/min during trial
Chest X-ray showing bibasilar atelectasis
questions.explanation: Airway protection is essential for successful extubation.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mr. Rossi, a 25-year-old primigravida in active labor in a labor and delivery unit who is receiving continuous electronic fetal monitoring. The monitor shows a pattern of V-shaped decelerations unrelated to contractions.

What is the nurse's priority intervention based on the fetal monitor tracing?
options: Increase the IV fluid rate
Encourage the client to blow in short breaths and not push
Prepare for immediate cesarean section
Discontinue the oxytocin infusion immediately
Reposition the client to the left lateral or knee-chest position
Administer oxygen via nasal cannula at 2 L/min
questions.explanation: Pushing before full dilation can cause cervical edema and lacerations.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of injury treatment and safety assessment for a 32-year-old presenting to the ED with a wrist fracture (Ms. Gomez) in an emergency department, the nurse performs an assessment. The client has multiple bruises in various stages of healing and partner refuses to leave the room.

What is the nurse's priority action?
options: Document findings objectively using body maps and photographs with consent
Partner appears concerned and attentive
Injuries in various stages of healing with inconsistent explanations
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
Client denies abuse when partner is present
Interview the client privately without the partner present
questions.explanation: Thorough documentation supports legal proceedings and continuity of care.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a community health telehealth follow-up is discussing the care plan for Ms. Chen, a 29-year-old with type 1 diabetes experiencing viral gastroenteritis, who is receiving basal-bolus insulin. The client has been vomiting but can sip clear liquids.

Which instruction should the nurse prioritize for preventing ketosis?
options: Take double the usual correction bolus at bedtime
Check blood glucose and ketones every 3 to 4 hours
Contact the provider for persistent fever or moderate ketones
Avoid electrolyte drinks because they contain sodium
Hold all insulin doses until solid food resumes
Skip ketone testing if glucose stays under 180 mg/dL
questions.explanation: Frequent monitoring catches hypoglycemia or ketosis early during illness.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 74-year-old with acute decompensated heart failure (Ms. Chenoweth) in a cardiac step-down unit to administer IV furosemide bolus every 4 hours. The client has lost 1.5 kg since admission and labs are pending.

What cue should the nurse address first during high-dose diuresis?
options: Lung sounds improved from coarse crackles to fine bibasilar crackles
Net negative output of 1 liter over 8 hours
Sodium level of 134 mEq/L
Blood pressure drops to 82/50 mm Hg with dizziness
Serum creatinine rising from 1.0 to 1.8 mg/dL overnight
Client requests assistance to the bathroom every two hours
questions.explanation: Symptomatic hypotension indicates excessive volume removal.

questions.text:
In an emergency department, the nurse is evaluating a 45-year-old with myasthenia gravis presenting with severe weakness (Ms. Yamamoto) who is receiving edrophonium test consideration. The client has been taking pyridostigmine regularly but had a recent dosage increase.

Which assessment finding helps differentiate myasthenic from cholinergic crisis?
options: Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
Prepare for intubation with declining respiratory effort
Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Fasciculations, increased salivation, and miosis with bradycardia
Ptosis, diplopia, and dysphagia with normal pupil size
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
questions.explanation: Both crisis types can cause respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text:
A nurse in a burn ICU is managing the care of Ms. Yamamoto, a 40-year-old with 35% TBSA full-thickness burns from a house fire, who is undergoing Parkland formula fluid resuscitation. The client was injured 2 hours ago and has two large-bore IVs.

Which formula guides initial fluid replacement?
options: Urine output consistently below 30 mL/hour despite aggressive fluids
Client reports severe pain at burn sites
Urine output maintained at 30-50 mL/hour or 0.5 mL/kg/hour
Blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg
Hematocrit elevation to 52%
Administer half of calculated 24-hour fluid volume in the first 8 hours
questions.explanation: Oliguria indicates inadequate resuscitation requiring rate adjustment.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mr. Lopez, a 25-year-old with family history of anesthesia complications in a surgical suite who is receiving emergency protocol activation. End-tidal CO2 is rapidly rising with muscle rigidity noted.

Which medication should the nurse prepare to administer?
options: Obtain arterial blood gas to assess metabolic acidosis
Rapidly rising end-tidal CO2 with unexplained tachycardia and rigidity
Temperature spiking to 105°F (40.6°C) or higher
Discontinue all triggering agents and hyperventilate with 100% oxygen
Initiate active cooling measures
Family history of unexplained perioperative death
questions.explanation: Early signs of MH hypermetabolic state requiring immediate action.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 70-year-old taking NSAIDs for arthritis with sudden weakness (Mr. Carter) in a medical unit. The client is receiving IV proton pump inhibitor infusion. Hemoglobin dropped from 12 to 8 g/dL overnight.

Which assessment finding indicates hypovolemic shock?
options: Type and crossmatch for packed red blood cells
Nasogastric tube insertion to assess gastric contents
Bowel sounds present in all four quadrants
Heart rate 120/min with blood pressure 88/54 mm Hg
Establish large-bore IV access and initiate rapid fluid replacement
Client reports epigastric pain
questions.explanation: Prepare for transfusion as hemoglobin is likely to drop further.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in an inpatient behavioral health unit, the nurse checks on Ms. Okafor, a 17-year-old admitted for major depressive disorder, who is receiving SSRIs and cognitive behavioral therapy. The client is on 15-minute checks.

Which cue indicates the safety plan is failing?
options: Client refuses to contract for safety after disclosing a lethal plan
Client requests extra art supplies for distraction
Client attends all therapy groups and participates
Client journals feelings during group therapy
Client sleeps six hours overnight
Client states, 'I finally figured out how to make the pain stop tonight.'
questions.explanation: Refusal indicates the plan is active and requires continuous observation.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of post-operative clients requiring various interventions (Dr. Bennett) in a surgical recovery unit. The client's current regimen includes post-op care protocols. Staffing is adequate with a mix of RNs, LPNs, and UAPs.

Which client care activity requires RN assessment and cannot be delegated?
options: Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
Document intake and output measurements
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Assist a client with ambulation using a gait belt
Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
questions.explanation: Initial assessments require RN clinical judgment and cannot be delegated.

questions.text:
While assessing a 55-year-old with head injury and impaired swallowing (Mr. Okoye) in a rehabilitation unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving bolus tube feedings four times daily. The client develops sudden coughing and respiratory distress during feeding.

Which assessment finding requires immediate intervention?
options: Client reports feeling bloated
Verify tube placement by checking pH of aspirate and comparing to X-ray
Gastric residual volume of 350 mL on consecutive checks
Sudden respiratory distress with diminished breath sounds
Flush the tube with 30 mL water before and after feeding
Gastric residual of 75 mL
questions.explanation: Confirming gastric placement prevents pulmonary administration.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of inotropic support and mechanical circulatory support consideration for a 66-year-old with acute MI presenting with hypotension and pulmonary edema (Ms. Harper) in a cardiac catheterization lab, the nurse performs an assessment. The client has cold, clammy skin with decreased urine output.

What intervention should the nurse anticipate?
options: Prepare for intra-aortic balloon pump or mechanical circulatory support
Blood pressure 88/60 mm Hg
Administer morphine for chest pain and anxiety
Initiate dobutamine to improve contractility and cardiac output
Avoid IV fluid boluses that would worsen pulmonary edema
Lactate level elevated at 3.2 mmol/L
questions.explanation: Refractory cardiogenic shock may require mechanical assistance.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 55-year-old with suspected urosepsis (Mr. Carter) in an emergency department. The client is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV fluid bolus. The client arrived with fever, confusion, and hypotension.

Which assessment finding is the earliest indicator of septic shock?
options: White blood cell count of 18,000/mm³
Administer 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus within the first 3 hours
Urine output of 35 mL/hour after fluid bolus
Obtain blood cultures before initiating antibiotics
Mean arterial pressure drops below 65 mm Hg despite fluids
Temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C)
questions.explanation: Early aggressive fluid resuscitation is a core sepsis bundle element.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Brown, a 30-year-old at 33 weeks' gestation with severe preeclampsia in a labor and delivery suite, indicate active treatment with magnesium sulfate at 2 g/hour. The nurse performs hourly assessments while antihypertensives run concurrently.

Which cue signals magnesium sulfate toxicity?
options: Client describes mild nausea
Magnesium level reported at 5.5 mg/dL
Serum magnesium level of 9.0 mg/dL
Respiratory rate that falls to 10 breaths per minute
Blood pressure decreases from 158/102 to 146/94
Client reports feeling warm and flushed
questions.explanation: Levels above the therapeutic range of 4-7 mg/dL indicate toxicity.

questions.text:
While assessing a 40-year-old with bipolar disorder (Mr. Yang) in an inpatient psychiatric unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving stabilization of acute mania. The client is pacing rapidly, talking loudly, and intruding on others.

What is the nurse's priority action to ensure safety?
options: Administer a sedative immediately
I have given away my prized guitar collection
Ask the client why they feel this way
Contract for safety
Assign a staff member to stay with the client at all times (1:1 observation)
Walk with the client to a quiet area and speak in a calm, low voice
questions.explanation: Giving away possessions is a classic warning sign of impending suicide attempt.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 32-year-old post-central line insertion with sudden dyspnea (Ms. Silva) in a medical ICU regarding supplemental oxygen. The client received a subclavian line 30 minutes ago.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Subcutaneous emphysema palpable at the insertion site
Unilateral chest pain worsening with deep breathing
Chest X-ray confirmation before treatment
Hypotension, distended neck veins, and rapid deterioration
Prepare for immediate needle thoracostomy followed by chest tube insertion
Tracheal deviation away from the affected side with severe dyspnea
questions.explanation: Hemodynamic compromise from impaired venous return requires immediate needle decompression.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 28-year-old at a prenatal visit appearing anxious and withdrawn (Ms. Silva) in an outpatient obstetric clinic. Current therapy includes routine prenatal care. The client minimizes injuries and partner controls all conversation.

What is the nurse's priority action?
options: Client denies abuse when partner is present
Document findings objectively using body maps and photographs with consent
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
Partner appears concerned and attentive
Interview the client privately without the partner present
Injuries in various stages of healing with inconsistent explanations
questions.explanation: Thorough documentation supports legal proceedings and continuity of care.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Yamamoto (a 4-year-old with asthma exacerbation), is admitted to an emergency department for nebulized beta-agonists and steroids. The child has been receiving back-to-back treatments.

Which cue suggests impending respiratory failure?
options: Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
Altered mental status with lethargy
Heart rate 160/min while crying
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Pulse oximetry falling to 88% despite oxygen support
questions.explanation: Decreased responsiveness signals severe hypoxia and CO2 retention.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 28-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor (Mr. Rossi) in a labor and delivery suite regarding continuous external fetal monitoring. Contractions are occurring every 3 minutes lasting 60 seconds.

What action should the nurse take first upon observing this tracing?
options: Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
questions.explanation: Prolonged bradycardia suggests cord compression or placental abruption.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a pediatric emergency department, the nurse checks on Mr. Carter, a 3-year-old with suspected measles, who is receiving supportive care. The child has fever, cough, and characteristic rash.

Which infection requires airborne precautions?
options: Place the client in a negative pressure isolation room
Wear a surgical mask, which is sufficient for TB
Cohort the client with another TB patient
Wear an N95 respirator before entering the room
Keep the door closed at all times
Standard precautions alone are adequate
questions.explanation: Airborne precautions require negative pressure to prevent organism spread.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 35-year-old postpartum client with type 1 diabetes (Ms. Nguyen) in a home-health visit. The client is receiving insulin pump therapy. She has a low-grade fever and poor appetite.

Which instruction should the nurse prioritize for glucose safety?
options: Contact the provider for persistent fever or moderate ketones
Avoid electrolyte drinks because they contain sodium
Skip ketone testing if glucose stays under 180 mg/dL
Sip 8 to 12 ounces of carb-containing fluids each hour
Hold all insulin doses until solid food resumes
Take double the usual correction bolus at bedtime
questions.explanation: Escalation criteria help prevent DKA progression.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a pediatric clinic is discussing the care plan for Ms. Nguyen, a 9-month-old infant, who is receiving well-child checkup. The nurse is discussing home safety and developmental milestones with the parents.

What is the most appropriate toy for this child?
options: Speaking 3-5 words
Not pulling up to a standing position
My baby sits without support
Give the child a 50-piece jigsaw puzzle
I can leave the baby in the bathtub for a minute to get a towel
Provide a medical kit or puppets for dramatic play
questions.explanation: By 15 months, a child should be walking or at least cruising/standing. Not pulling up is a delay.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a birthing center is discussing the care plan for Mr. Brown, a 30-year-old multipara at 39 weeks gestation, who is receiving labor augmentation with oxytocin. Contractions are occurring every 1.5 minutes and lasting 90 seconds.

What is the nurse's priority intervention based on the fetal monitor tracing?
options: Administer oxygen via nasal cannula at 2 L/min
Increase the IV fluid rate
Prepare for immediate cesarean section
Encourage the client to blow in short breaths and not push
Discontinue the oxytocin infusion immediately
Reposition the client to the left lateral or knee-chest position
questions.explanation: Pushing before full dilation can cause cervical edema and lacerations.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 58-year-old receiving IV morphine for post-operative pain (Mr. Lopez) in a surgical recovery unit regarding PCA morphine with basal rate. The client has obstructive sleep apnea and received a bolus dose 30 minutes ago.

What intervention should the nurse have readily available?
options: Blood pressure slightly decreased from baseline
Respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute with sedation score of 3
Inability to arouse the client with verbal or tactile stimulation
Client sleeping but easily arousable with normal respirations
Pinpoint pupils with decreased level of consciousness
Client reports pain level of 6/10
questions.explanation: Bradypnea with deep sedation indicates dangerous respiratory depression.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old with a central venous line (Mx. Santos) is being treated in an ICU with central line dressing change. The nurse and a student nurse are performing the procedure together.

Which action by the nurse requires immediate correction?
options: Pour the saline solution without splashing onto the sterile field
Reach over the sterile field to grab a supply
Keep the sterile field in direct line of sight at all times
Place the sterile field 1 inch from the edge of the table
Discard the entire sterile field and start over with a new kit
Use a sterile gloved hand to adjust the face mask
questions.explanation: Moisture allows bacteria to travel through the sterile drape (wicking), contaminating the field.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old with known Alzheimer's disease now more confused (Mr. Okoye) is being treated in a skilled nursing facility with urinary catheter for retention. Staff notes worsening agitation over the past 24 hours.

Which factor is most likely contributing to the acute confusion?
options: Client cannot recall short-term events
Family requests pharmacologic sedation
Recent addition of multiple new medications including opioids and anticholinergics
Gradual cognitive decline over several years
Acute onset of confusion with fluctuating level of consciousness
Investigate for underlying infection, hypoxia, or metabolic disturbance
questions.explanation: Polypharmacy, especially with high-risk meds, commonly triggers delirium.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of medication reconciliation for a 76-year-old with newly prescribed medications after hospitalization (Mr. Rossi) in a transitional care clinic, the nurse performs an assessment. Home medications include anticoagulants, NSAIDs, and antiplatelets.

What adverse effect is most concerning with this medication combination?
options: Diphenhydramine prescribed for sleep in an 82-year-old
Client sees multiple specialists
Family helps manage medication administration
Client uses a weekly pill organizer
Concurrent use of warfarin, aspirin, and ibuprofen
New cognitive impairment with urinary retention and dry mouth
questions.explanation: Beers Criteria identifies antihistamines as potentially inappropriate for elderly due to anticholinergic effects.

questions.text:
While assessing a 65-year-old post-cardiac catheterization with contrast dye (Mr. Kaur) in a cardiac step-down unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving IV hydration protocol. Urine output has decreased to 20 mL/hour over the past 4 hours.

Which laboratory finding is the earliest indicator of acute kidney injury?
options: Potassium level of 6.2 mEq/L with peaked T waves on ECG
BUN/creatinine ratio of 15:1
Urine specific gravity of 1.010
Serum creatinine increase of 0.3 mg/dL or more within 48 hours
Urine output less than 0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 consecutive hours
Client reports nausea and fatigue
questions.explanation: Hyperkalemia with cardiac changes is life-threatening in AKI.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old with schizophrenia taking haloperidol (Mr. Wallace) is being treated in a psychiatric outpatient clinic with typical antipsychotic medication. The client reports new muscle stiffness and difficulty swallowing.

Which adverse effect requires immediate intervention?
options: Client reports feeling drowsy in the afternoon
Weight gain of 5 pounds over 2 months
Involuntary tongue protrusion and facial grimacing
Temperature 104°F (40°C) with severe muscle rigidity and altered mental status
Teach client to report fever, sore throat, or flu-like symptoms immediately
Mild hand tremor noted during medication administration
questions.explanation: Acute dystonia requires immediate treatment with anticholinergic agents.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 22-year-old with a traumatic brain injury (Mx. Jordan) in a neuro ICU to administer ventricular drain with ICP monitoring. Sedation has been lightened for a neuro exam.

Which cue should prompt the nurse to prepare for rapid intervention?
options: Temperature of 99.2 F (37.3 C)
Unequal pupils with sluggish reaction to light
Urine output of 55 mL/hour
ICP waveform showing regular P1>P2 pattern
Client reports headache rated 4/10
Decorticate posturing noted during stimulation
questions.explanation: Anisocoria with sluggish response suggests herniation risk.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 16-year-old admitted for vaso-occlusive crisis (Ms. Okafor) in a hematology unit. The client is on patient-controlled analgesia. Temperature is 100.8°F with decreased breath sounds in the right base.

Which pain management strategy is most appropriate?
options: Hemoglobin of 8 g/dL
Initiate aggressive pain management with opioids around-the-clock
New onset fever, chest pain, and decreased oxygen saturation
Encourage bed rest to conserve energy
Administer IV fluids at 1.5 times maintenance to promote hemodilution
Client requests heating pad for painful joints
questions.explanation: Adequate analgesia is essential; use scheduled dosing rather than PRN only.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 60-year-old with pulmonary edema (Mr. Singh) in an ICU to administer continuous bumetanide infusion. Strict intake and output and telemetry monitoring are in place.

What cue should the nurse address first during high-dose diuresis?
options: Client requests assistance to the bathroom every two hours
Potassium level of 2.9 mEq/L
Client reports ringing in the ears after the push dose
Net negative output of 1 liter over 8 hours
Lung sounds improved from coarse crackles to fine bibasilar crackles
Sodium level of 134 mEq/L
questions.explanation: Severe hypokalemia predisposes the client to lethal arrhythmias.

questions.text:
While assessing a 35-year-old receiving IV antibiotics who suddenly develops hives and throat tightness (Ms. Patel) in a medical unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving epinephrine administration. The infusion was started 10 minutes ago.

What assessment finding confirms anaphylaxis?
options: Client reports feeling anxious and dizzy
Administer diphenhydramine 50 mg IV after epinephrine
Stop the infusion and maintain IV access with normal saline
Urticaria spreading across the chest and arms
Stridor, wheezing, and oxygen saturation dropping to 88%
Administer epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg IM into the lateral thigh immediately
questions.explanation: Remove the antigen source while preserving access for medications.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Ibrahim, a 24-year-old admitted for DKA now on hour 8 of treatment in a medical ICU, indicate active treatment with IV regular insulin and potassium replacement. Glucose has dropped to 180 mg/dL but pH remains 7.28.

Which complication requires immediate recognition during treatment?
options: Add potassium to IV fluids once level drops below 5.3 mEq/L
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
New onset headache, bradycardia, and altered mental status
Client reports extreme thirst
Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
questions.explanation: Insulin drives potassium intracellularly; replacement prevents cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour (Mr. Okoye) in a pre-procedure area. Current therapy includes informed consent process. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which situation requires the nurse to intervene before the procedure?
options: Family members are present and supportive
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Client appears nervous about the procedure
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
questions.explanation: Patient must be competent and alert to provide valid consent.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a pediatric emergency department is discussing the care plan for Ms. Patel, an 18-month-old with vomiting and diarrhea for 48 hours, who is receiving oral rehydration therapy. Parents report only 2 wet diapers in the past 24 hours.

What is the priority intervention for this child?
options: Capillary refill time greater than 3 seconds with cool extremities
Child is fussy and irritable
Slightly decreased skin turgor on the abdomen
Urine specific gravity of 1.025
Sunken fontanel, absent tears, and dry mucous membranes
Weight loss of 12% from pre-illness weight
questions.explanation: Indicates poor perfusion and potential hypovolemic shock.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Osei, a 55-year-old with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in an ICU, who is currently on continuous IV insulin infusion. The nurse is preparing to adjust the infusion rate based on blood glucose levels.

Which action is essential to prevent a medication error?
options: Administer the insulin via gravity drip
Decrease the heparin rate by 2 units/kg/hr
Stop the heparin infusion and notify the provider
Verify the insulin dose and rate with a second registered nurse
Obtain a serum digoxin level and potassium level
Administer the next dose of digoxin
questions.explanation: A PTT of 98 is >3x control, indicating high bleeding risk. The infusion should be held.

questions.text:
While assessing a 45-year-old on day 2 of chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma (Ms. Chen) in a cancer center, the nurse notes the client is receiving rasburicase administration. Urine output has been adequate at 150 mL/hour.

What intervention should the nurse prioritize?
options: Urine pH of 6.5
Cardiac monitor showing peaked T waves and widened QRS
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Potassium 6.8 mEq/L, phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL, calcium 6.9 mg/dL
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
questions.explanation: Life-threatening hyperkalemia requires emergent treatment.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 55-year-old with mitral valve stenosis (Ms. Chen) in an outpatient cardiology clinic. The client is on monitoring for valve replacement. The nurse is performing a focused cardiac assessment.

Based on the anatomy involved, what is the nurse's priority assessment?
options: Assess blood pressure in both arms to check for discrepancy
Palpate the carotid arteries simultaneously
Pulmonary venous congestion due to backward failure of the left ventricle
Right ventricular failure causing systemic congestion
Auscultate the second intercostal space right sternal border
Auscultate the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line
questions.explanation: A significant difference (>20 mmHg) suggests aortic dissection affecting subclavian arteries.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Yamamoto (a 68-year-old recovering from a mechanical mitral valve replacement), asks the nurse in a cardiac step-down unit about their warfarin with bridge therapy. The client takes herbal supplements at home and prepares leafy greens daily.

Which statement shows the client understands how to stay safe on warfarin with bridge therapy?
options: Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Keep vitamin K intake consistent rather than eliminating leafy vegetables
Keep a blood pressure log every morning
Report any bruising, nosebleeds, or black stools to the provider immediately
questions.explanation: Stable vitamin K consumption prevents sudden INR shifts.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Mr. Park, a 58-year-old female with dilated cardiomyopathy in a telemetry step-down unit, who is currently on continuous lidocaine infusion targeting ventricular trigeminy. The nurse is reviewing the rhythm strip during bedside rounds.

Which finding signals that the continuous lidocaine infusion targeting ventricular trigeminy should be paused?
options: Serum potassium that dropped from 4.2 to 3.1 mEq/L
Complaint of mild metallic taste
Sudden confusion and tremors noted during neurologic checks
Occasional premature ventricular contractions that match baseline frequency
Client reporting localized IV site warmth
Oxygen saturation trending 96% on 2 L/min nasal cannula
questions.explanation: Hypokalemia increases ventricular irritability and undermines lidocaine effectiveness.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of antibiotics for suspected bacterial superinfection for a 72-year-old with home oxygen presenting with worsening cough (Ms. Chen) in an emergency department, the nurse performs an assessment. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air.
